title: Effects of a Application (Flourish App) on Stress, Well-being and Emotional Regulation in Medical Students
description_brief: This protocol proposes a well-being program, delivered through an application for mobile devices, based on meditation and positive psychology principles such as human development, the improvement of virtues, quality of life and well-being. The investigators hypothesize that this program offered in mobile application may promote well-being, reduce stress related problems and improving emotional regulation in the participants. Objectives: To evaluate the effectiveness of a well-being program delivered through an application for mobile devices in a sample of medical students. Methods: Three hundred students of the undergraduate medical course of Albert Einstein Israelite Faculty will be recruited. The participants will be randomized in two groups of 150 participants each one, half of them in the control group (GC) and the other half to the intervention group (GI).
description_detailed:
INTRODUCTION: One population that presents an important vulnerability to stress is that of university students, facing several stressors, such as academic demands, time pressure and social adjustments. Medical students in particular may face additional challenges such as heavy workload, time commitment and the number of tests and assessments as well as the pressures of a clinical setting. Some highly successful programs in stress management are based on the principle of Mindfulness. On the other hand, Positive Psychology brings a new paradigm in terms of mental and emotional health, seeking to promote human development through the development of virtues, quality of life and well-being, instead of just treating disease. In the modern world not all people are willing to attend classroom training for several reasons. In this sense, a program offered in mobile application can be considered an interesting alternative for professionals that not only want to reduce stress-related symptoms, but also promote well-being.

MAIN OBJECTIVES: Evaluate the effects of a well-being program compared to a control program, both served on mobile applications, in reducing stress, increasing well-being and improving emotional regulation in a sample of medical students.

METHOD: For this purpose, 300 students of the undergraduate medical course of Albert Einstein Israelite Faculty. Participants will be randomized into groups of 150 each, half to the control group (CG) and the other half to the intervention group (IG). The IG will participate in the Flourish App Program, for 8 weeks, while the CG will have access to a control application. Then, after the evaluations, the CG will participate in the Flourish App Program, while the first group will not participate in any intervention. Before starting the program, after 4 and 8 weeks of the program, questions will be applied to assess the stress and well-being levels of participants in general and in relation to work. In addition, before and after each training period, questions will be applied to assess the stress and well-being levels of participants at the moment. Also, the Perceived Stress Scale, the 5-item World Health Organization Well-Being Index - WHO-5, the Mindful Attention Awareness Scale, the Self-Compassion Scale and the Difficulties in Emotion Regulation Scale will be applied too. Finally, at the end of the program, the Mobile Application Rating Scale - MARS will be applied.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a mobile well‑being program (Flourish App) based on meditation and positive‑psychology exercises intended to promote well‑being, reduce stress, and improve emotional regulation — i.e., it targets stress and emotion/behavioral symptoms rather than Alzheimer pathology or a pharmacologic cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search8turn0search0

Act: Key details extracted from the protocol — intervention = Flourish App (mobile application delivering meditation/positive‑psychology exercises), population = medical students, outcomes = well‑being, stress reduction, emotional regulation. This is a non‑pharmacologic psychological/behavioral intervention (no drug or placebo listed). Web search confirms Flourish is an app marketed as an evidence‑based well‑being/mental‑health companion using positive psychology and mindfulness techniques. citeturn0search8turn0search1

No ambiguity from the description that would place it in the other Alzheimer‑focused categories, so classification is neuropsychiatric symptom improvement. citeturn0search0turn0search8

Act: Extracted details — intervention = Flourish App (AI/science‑based positive‑psychology/mindfulness mobile app); population (per protocol) = medical students; outcomes = well‑being, stress reduction, emotional regulation. This is a behavioral/psychological intervention with no drug, biologic, or molecular target to map to CADRO categories A–Q or R (multi‑target). citeturn0search5turn0search0

Reflect: CADRO categories describe biological or pharmacologic targets (e.g., Amyloid beta, Tau, Inflammation, Synaptic Plasticity). A purely behavioral/psychological mobile app does not engage a specified biological target in those categories, so per instructions it should be classified as 'T) Other'. The user’s supplied reasoning (neuropsychiatric symptom improvement) is consistent with a non‑biologic intervention; therefore I assign T) Other. citeturn0search5

Web search results (supporting evidence): Flourish Science / Flourish App describes an AI‑enabled, evidence‑based positive‑psychology and mindfulness app used in college settings with published trials showing benefits for student well‑being and stress reduction. citeturn0search5 App Store listings describe Flourish as a mental‑wellness/AI companion offering meditation, breathing exercises, affirmations, and related tools to boost mood and reduce stress. citeturn0search0turn0search1
